SENT.plain: A 43-year-old woman with anterior spinal artery syndrome was admitted with complaints of tetraplegia and urinary retention
Her bladder had capacity of more than 500 ml and was inactive, with low voltage of external urethral sphincter
She was treated with distigmine bromide and intermittent catheterization
50 days later, urodynamic study showed normal bladder and incomplete coordination of external sphincter
A 78-year-old man had chief complaints of urinary retention and paraplegia
A catheter was left indwell for 6 months
Then he was treated with intermittent catheterization, but urgency incontinence was still observed
We discussed the therapy of neurogenic bladder due to the anterior spinal artery syndrome
